trans-unit.source: Working with Azure AD Application Proxy Connectors | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Working with Azure AD Application Proxy Connectors | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Covers how to create and manage groups of Connectors in Azure AD Application Proxy.
trans-unit.target: Covers how to create and manage groups of Connectors in Azure AD Application Proxy.

trans-unit.source: Publish applications on separate networks and locations using Connector groups
trans-unit.target: Publish applications on separate networks and locations using Connector groups

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Application Proxy is a feature that is available only if you upgraded to the Premium or Basic edition of Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Application Proxy is a feature that is available only if you upgraded to the Premium or Basic edition of Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Active Directory editions](active-directory-editions.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Active Directory editions](active-directory-editions.md).

trans-unit.source: Connector groups are useful for a number of various scenarios, including:
trans-unit.target: Connector groups are useful for a number of various scenarios, including:

trans-unit.source: Sites with multiple interconnected datacenters in which you want to keep as much traffic within the datacenter as possible, and not utilize cross-datacenter links that are usually expensive and have high latency.
trans-unit.target: Sites with multiple interconnected datacenters in which you want to keep as much traffic within the datacenter as possible, and not utilize cross-datacenter links that are usually expensive and have high latency.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy Connectors in each datacenter to serve only the applications that reside within the datacenter, and save valuable cross-datacenter links and provide an entirely transparent experience to your users.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy Connectors in each datacenter to serve only the applications that reside within the datacenter, and save valuable cross-datacenter links and provide an entirely transparent experience to your users.

trans-unit.source: Managing applications installed on isolated networks that are not part of the main corporate network.
trans-unit.target: Managing applications installed on isolated networks that are not part of the main corporate network.

trans-unit.source: You can use Connector groups to install dedicated Connectors for isolated networks to also enable isolation of applications to the network.
trans-unit.target: You can use Connector groups to install dedicated Connectors for isolated networks to also enable isolation of applications to the network.

trans-unit.source: For applications installed on IaaS for cloud access, Connector groups provide a common service to secure the access to all of them without creating additional dependency on your corporate network or fragmenting the experience.
trans-unit.target: For applications installed on IaaS for cloud access, Connector groups provide a common service to secure the access to all of them without creating additional dependency on your corporate network or fragmenting the experience.

trans-unit.source: Connectors can be installed on every cloud datacenter and serve only applications that reside in this network.
trans-unit.target: Connectors can be installed on every cloud datacenter and serve only applications that reside in this network.

trans-unit.source: You can install several Connectors to achieve high availability.
trans-unit.target: You can install several Connectors to achieve high availability.

trans-unit.source: Support for multi-forest environments in which specific Connectors can be deployed per forest and set to serve specific applications.
trans-unit.target: Support for multi-forest environments in which specific Connectors can be deployed per forest and set to serve specific applications.

trans-unit.source: Connector groups can be used in Disaster Recovery sites to either detect failover or as backup for the main site.
trans-unit.target: Connector groups can be used in Disaster Recovery sites to either detect failover or as backup for the main site.

trans-unit.source: Connector groups can also be used to serve multiple companies from a single tenant.
trans-unit.target: Connector groups can also be used to serve multiple companies from a single tenant.

trans-unit.source: Working with Connector groups
trans-unit.target: Working with Connector groups

trans-unit.source: In order to group your Connectors, you have to make sure you [installed multiple Connectors](active-directory-application-proxy-enable.md), and that you name them and then group them.
trans-unit.target: In order to group your Connectors, you have to make sure you [installed multiple Connectors](active-directory-application-proxy-enable.md), and that you name them and then group them.

trans-unit.source: Finally you have to assign them to specific apps.
trans-unit.target: Finally you have to assign them to specific apps.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create Connector groups
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create Connector groups

trans-unit.source: You can create as many Connector groups as you want.
trans-unit.target: You can create as many Connector groups as you want.

trans-unit.source: Connector group creation is accomplished in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Connector group creation is accomplished in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Select your directory and click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: Select your directory and click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: Then, under Application Proxy, click **Manage Connector Groups** and create a new Connector group by giving the group a name:
trans-unit.target: Then, under Application Proxy, click **Manage Connector Groups** and create a new Connector group by giving the group a name:

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Assign Connectors to your groups
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Assign Connectors to your groups

trans-unit.source: Once the Connector groups are created, move the Connectors to the appropriate group.
trans-unit.target: Once the Connector groups are created, move the Connectors to the appropriate group.

trans-unit.source: Under **Application Proxy**, click **Manage Connectors** and under **Group**, select the group you want for each Connector.
trans-unit.target: Under **Application Proxy**, click **Manage Connectors** and under **Group**, select the group you want for each Connector.

trans-unit.source: Note that it might take the Connectors up to 10 minutes to become active in the new group.
trans-unit.target: Note that it might take the Connectors up to 10 minutes to become active in the new group.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Assign applications to your Connector groups
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Assign applications to your Connector groups

trans-unit.source: The last step is to set each application to the Connector group that will serve it.
trans-unit.target: The last step is to set each application to the Connector group that will serve it.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, in your directory, select the Application you want to assign to the group, click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, in your directory, select the Application you want to assign to the group, click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: Under **Connector group**, select the group you want the application to use.
trans-unit.target: Under **Connector group**, select the group you want the application to use.

trans-unit.source: This change is immediately applied.
trans-unit.target: This change is immediately applied.

trans-unit.source: For more information on publishing applications, see [Publish applications using your own domain name](active-directory-application-proxy-custom-domains.md)
trans-unit.target: For more information on publishing applications, see [Publish applications using your own domain name](active-directory-application-proxy-custom-domains.md)
